description:
Having had Reaper as my only DAW for many years on Windows, I tried to use it in Linux with inconsistent results. Now that I have abandoned Windows for good, I need to get a new "workflow" that doesn't involved only Reaper. 
I found Ardour6 very easy to switch to, first off, and have worked on a couple projects as tests in Ardour, and found it to be very capable DAW. 

What has BLOWN me away though, is that somehow when using my Zoom R24 as a USB Audio Interface, instead of having only the MAIN L/R OUTPUT as the audio that gets received by the DAW, it's actually showing me all 8 MICROPHONE/XLR inputs! 

The R24 is a sweet little unit with 8 XLR+1/4" combo inputs.

The specs for the Zoom R24 is that all 8 mics get "mixed" to Stereo Output that goes over USB to the DAW input. 

 I've used this Zoom R24 with multiple Windows machines, and only had the Stereo output available as a source. 

Now with Ardour6, I am able to record the mic inputs to separate tracks! 

I tested with my guitar (split into two signal chains) and a vocal mic, so 3 inputs, and was able to record all 3 into Ardour6 onto their own tracks.

Only Ardour6 DAW sees it. Any other DAW I've tried to use the Zoom R24 as the Audio Interface... just the main stereo output 

How is this possible? Maybe I misunderstood the capabilities of my equipment all these years? LOL 

1.21 GIGWATTS !!??  Somehow Ardour has supercharged my Zoom R24 into an 8x8 I/O audio interface?

I have noticed complaints with how complicated Ardour is to new beginners. This should in no way be seen as a valid complaint against Ardour. You would see the same complaints against Protools, logic, Cakewalk ect... If you are new to audio engineering try something simpler (audacity, garage band, traction) Please don't download and leave a bad review of a program that you don't understand how to use. If you know or have any experience with DAW and you use Ardour and have a legitimate problem with it then I fully understand your complaint. But if you are trying to learn on any Daw you will find quite the learning curve to get through.
summary: There is no Easy way to learn how to use a professional DAW

Hail the king of open source DAWs! The team behind Ardour have every reason to be proud, as this is definitely able to compete with Cubase, Pro Tools and all the rest. And it's free!

The UI is functional, and what you would expect from a professional-level DAW. It has all the usual bells and whistles along with some cool design choices that I like. For example, the partitioning of tracks and Mixer into two totally separate environments is a small stroke of genious in my book, and allows for a more clean workspace. I have done audio and MIDI recording, editing and processing along with sending to dedicated buses for FX or external devices. And I have only begun to scratch the surface of this beast.

Because of the extreme versatility of the program, the learning curve is as expected pretty steep, and the manual is not the first place I would search for answers. But stick with it, and you have an immensely powerful tool at your disposal.

Pros:
-Full MIDI implementation (send, receive, compose, FX)
-FX sends and processors, with plugin support (lots of incuded FX plugins!)
-Wide array of monitoring capabilities for mixing/mastering
-Plug & play on external devices (MIDI controllers, synthesizers, soundcards)
-UI is actually not that bad (love the Editor/Mixer partitioning)
-absolutely love the "tap tempo" option for setting project tempo

Cons:
-No factory default export to mp3
-MIDI Note Off seems a little buggy (stuck notes -needs further testing)
-As with other DAWS I've tried except FL Studio, it hogs the sound driver, so no other program can use it

description: Initially it worked ,but now not loading the session files,"unable to load session " message occurs every time when I start. So i uninstalled it. MIDI not working.

I've tried LMMS, Cakewalk, Pro Tools (first), Qtractor, and others, and Ardour crushes all of them. Pro Tools, which Ardour is a direct competitor to, was a freaking mess when I tried it and lacked seemingly essential features. Ardour behaves similarly to Pro Tools, except it dodges ridiculous issues like poor performance, frequent crashing, and the inability to freely bind MIDI controls.

	Ardour has a fairly clean and usable interface and workflow, though you'll have to get used to it. If you haven't used a DAW before, don't expect to be able to jump right in easily.

	Ardour has great support for standards, allowing the use of LV2, VST, and LADSPA plugins. It supports JACK, ALSA, and Pulseaudio on Linux, as well as the respective sound systems of Windows and Mac. It supports any sound card or audio interface that your OS supports. You can access automatic bindings for many MIDI controllers, or create bindings manually for uncommon devices.

	The interface is a simple one-window interface by default. Selecting a track will reveal its mixer strip. You edit MIDI directly in the timeline. You can use and detach a separate mixer window like is the default in Pro Tools if you want.

	Ardour also comes with basic plugins for composing and mixing.

I should address a few complaints that I frequently see about Ardour:

"Ardour isn't free software, you have to pay for binaries!": First of all, you only need to pay for binaries if you are getting them directly from ardour.org. You don't have to pay a penny for the binaries in repositories. Second, "free" is an older term that refers to freedom, not price. Think of Ardour as an "open-source" application.

"I can't get it to load a session" or "it won't play any sound": You need to properly configure your audio server and settings. ALSA is the most fail-proof option to choose when loading Ardour. If JACK gives you issues, configure it for real-time processing. These issues are not Ardour's problem.

"Ardour is clunky and hard to use" : Even if you already use a DAW you still need to put work into learning Ardour's interface. This goes for any professional software.

"It won't open" or "this is broken, it crashes all the time" : It might not be compiled correctly. If you compiled it yourself, make sure you are using the correct versions of the libraries that are recommended by the developers. If you are using a binary compiled for your OS, try compiling it yourself or using the official binaries. If issues persist, something could be wrong with your operating system.
summary: Outstanding software, absolutely crushes Pro Tools

description: Ardour 6 is out. But this is still 5 :(
the beautifull app I found in the space,,
I use it for mixing and it works perfectly

I will preface by saying I have not worked on any other serious DAW as I was using audacity before this which doesn't really count. With that in mind I do have a rough understanding of other DAWs based on conversations I've had with other audio engineers/musician.

if you are the kind of person that likes to have complete and total control over your software this is the DAW for you. I've been working with it for about 6 months and it has been an absolute dream. From what I understand of other DAWs it will take you longer to get used to the most however the pay off is absolutely worth it.

If you want some good tutorials on how to use it I recommend looking up unfa on YouTube as they have some invaluable resources on their channel.

It scales beautifully to multi monitor setups (something very important to me as I am a screen real estate junkie with five monitors) from my experience you will ideally want at least two monitors or take the time to configure virtual desktops and hotkeys to switch between them ( With KDE my recommendation is a 3x3 grid with media+wasd to move through the grid)

A huge time saver is the creation of template project files to save you the time of setting up all of the bus mapping and general configurations of a base project.

I would not recommend this software for most people, however for the niche group of people that love to have a powerful piece of software that is tweakable to no end... This is honestly the perfect solution.

It's also worth noting that if you're on Ardour5 it is full of bugs, if You're on 6 though she works like a charm. You will probably have to make sure you're on the latest Ubuntu release as I don't think 6 is available on 20.04 LTS
